title: Not the best
text: This market has lots of decent local craft items but the problem is some of the stall holders are so pushy it wears you down, even experienced travellers avoid it

title: Nothing Special
text: We went here because we were in the area. Nothing special. Just the usual stuff that is available on every street corner in The Gambia

title: WELCOME TO THE GAMBIA
text:
Very interesting to see Arts and crafts batik in senegambia craft market for the Best local Guide to show you around please kindly contact +220 7647423 

Thank you for your kindly attention! 
Welcome to the Gambia smiling coast of West Africa

title: Average dusty local outdoor market
text:
Typical African market where the same trinkets, crafts, textiles etc are being sold, mostly very dusty. Am the above can easily be found in any same place. 

Each stall sells everything the same as their neighbours. Even having multiple stalls. 

I certainly saw, like for like, in Tanzania and Zanzibar. 

DO not accept the first price. Offer a 1/3 and meet in the middle unless you're very generous and pay their inflated price 

All good fun and they certainly won't sell at a loss 

They're great vendors, chatty, friendly and interested in where  you're from.

title: Goede souvenirs, veel dwingend aangesproken
text: Een prima kleine markt voor echt Afrikaanse souveniers (tassen, sleutelhangers, beelden, schilderijen, sieraden). Ontzettend aandringen van verkopers, kon geen stap zetten zonder dwingend aangesproken te worden. Als tourist wordt dubbele prijs gevraagd, veel vanaf gepraat.

title: BELLE CREATIVITE
text:
Après la visite du parc , nous avons eu le plaisir d'arpenter le marché artisanal de Sénégambie, un lieu vibrant et coloré où les traditions locales s'expriment à travers une myriade d'objets artisanaux. Dès notre arrivée, nous avons été accueillis par un kaléidoscope de couleurs, avec des étals débordant d'objets en bois sculpté, des masques de cérémonie africaine aux motifs mystérieux, des tissus batik aux teintes chatoyantes, des vêtements traditionnels et des bijoux étincelants.
L'accueil des marchands était chaleureux mais pressant, avec chacun d'eux vantant la beauté et la qualité de leurs produits. Parmi les objets exposés, nous avons été particulièrement séduits par les magnifiques sculptures en bois, témoignant du talent et du savoir-faire des artisans locaux. Les masques de cérémonie africaine, chargés d'histoire et de symbolisme, ont également captivé notre imagination.
Les tissus batik, avec leurs motifs complexes et leurs couleurs vives, ont ajouté une touche de dynamisme au marché, tandis que les vêtements traditionnels ont offert un aperçu fascinant de la culture locale. Les bijoux, élaborés avec soin et ornés de perles et de pierres précieuses, ont étincelé sous le soleil ardent.
Parmi les trésors du marché, nous avons également découvert de magnifiques tableaux sur toile, véritables œuvres d'art qui reflètent la richesse culturelle et artistique de la région. Chaque tableau racontait une histoire, capturant l'essence et la beauté de la vie en Sénégambie.
Notre visite au marché artisanal de Sénégambie a été une expérience inoubliable, nous plongeant au cœur de la culture et de l'artisanat local. Entre les couleurs éclatantes, les objets magnifiquement travaillés et l'ambiance animée du marché, nous avons été transportés dans un monde de beauté et de créativité.
VOYAGEAVECNOUS.COM
FB ET INSTA AUTOURDUMONDE2023

title: Hard selling at its worst - avoid this place
text: I felt pressured into buying items that I did not need from stall holders. It was not a nice experience and it was not what I expected. I would not go there again, the prices are inflated and if you are not a haggler you get ripped off.

title: Beautyfull stuff (clothes, souveniers)
text:
There are beautyfull stuff at the market. People are very kind but sometimes its anoying they push you to buy stuff. Let people see for themselves. Pushing to buy is also pushing away. 
Because we left de market and did not buy anything. The 3rth visit i bought Some stuff. 
I bought 6 dresses and 2 Animal Crafts. Very beautyfull.

title: Not suitable for wheelchair users
text: One of us is a wheelchair user. The taxi controller knew that and he would also have known that the trip would be disastrous but still he let us go. The road surfaces are so poor that a wheelchair can’t negotiate them. As a result we saw nothing of the market. The taxi driver dropped us outside a shop having parked the taxi 200 yards away. We waited 30 minutes for him to pick us up because of the one way road system and the heavy traffic. Maybe others would enjoy the market but that was our experience.

title: Craftmarkets
text: Een van de vele craftmarkets. Klein maar prima voor een uurtje. Wel veel aandringen van de verkopers en weinig acceptatie van het woord nee.

title: Not hugely impressed
text:
Nothing special about this market ,better bargains can be found elsewhere ,
Some of the traders are rude especially the first wood carving stall on the left

title: Leuke markt met hele lieve verkopers
text: De onwijs super lieve mensen op de Craft Market verkopen veelal dezelfde spullen en voor dezelfde prijs; kleding, houtsnijwerk, armbandjes, sieraden, pinda's enz. Afdingen kan, maar besef wel dat iedere Dalasi voor hen heel veel waarde heeft. De arme, maar o zo vriendelijke mensen zijn zo dankbaar voor iedere Dalasi die ze verdienen.

title: Tough Shopping
text: 99% of the stalls sells the same wares. But if you have the patience to walk around and bear with the 'hassle' of the stall owners calling you....you will find something different...just like we did.

title: Honeymoon visit
text: Great little market full of woodworking pieces jewellery and trinkets you will be approached a lot just remember be polite and just say only looking but enjoy the African experience

title: Be prepared to have a lot of options
text: It’s beyond impressive that the people of Africa have kept traditional crafting so alive and well. Everything is one of a kind, and so authentic! MOST ITEMS ARE HAND MADE. From paintings, to carvings, to jewelry. You’re sure to fall in love. Also, everything is so well priced. Be sure to enter with some self-control, because it’s easy to want to buy every single thing you see!

title: Dont Go Alone
text:
Senegambia market is huge filled with people shoulder to shoulder selling everything from sunglasses to cement and anything inbetween.
The roads are packed with taxis ,stalls it looks totaly unorganised  but i am sure it.
If you get the chance go just to experience Gambian life but do take a guide

title: Mooie herinneringen aan Gambia
text:
Badou and Tapha jewelleries zijn erg vriendelijke mannen met mooie prettig geprijsde sieraden. 

Ze zitten rechtsachter in de hoek

title: sehenswert
text: alle Preise verhandeln, Verkäufer teilweise recht aufdringlich, angenehm schattiger Ort, liegt günstig in der Nähe von diversen Restaurants mitten in der Stadt

title: Good market
text: Much things to look at and much things to but. Remember that you need to discuss the Price and get it down at least 50%

title: Ferie
text: Meget spændende,meget anderledes end andre markeder vi har været på, det kan være svært at se ordentligt på noget da alle sælgere er meget anmasende, men samtidig er de også utrolige søde og smilende.

title: Einkaufen mal anstrengend
text: Ein kleiner und schöner Markt zum Anschauen und Staunen, aber leider zum Aussuchen und in Ruhe aussuchen leider nicht gedacht. Die Händler sind etwas anstrengend in ihrer Verkaufskultur.

title: Desparate
text: After visiting gambia several times i enjoyed talking to the locals in the market and they made me very welcome.  Unfortunately this time as no tourists coming in i found it the opposite . I was shouted at by one store owner as i was effecting his business i know thus is a difficult time for gambians but found it very hostile and some if them very angry and aggressive i certainly wont be visiting again

title: Weinig verrassende markt
text: Bijna iedereen verkoopt dezelfde spullen voor dezelfde prijs. En spreekt je aan. Afdingen is aan te bevelen. Heb wel een paar zelf beschilderde theedoosjes gekocht. Niet heel bijzonder, wel uniek.

title: hassle !
text: Such a pity because I wanted to buy several things for the family, but the hassling and pushing by he vendors drove me away very quickly. If they'd just leave people to look, they'd make more sales.

title: De onderhandelingen blijven typisch
text: Wij zijn enkele keren op deze markt geweest. Het is een leuke “kraft”markt. Ook al hebben per kraampje veel hetzelfde, veel houtsnijwerk maken ze zelf. Je kunt de kunstenaars ook gewoon aan het werk zien. Wat wel voor ons wennen was, was dat een deal geen deal is. Als je een bedrag afspreekt en ze moeten wisselgeld teruggeven dan kunnen ze dit nooit. Er vindt een heel spel plaats dat ze elders gaan wisselen, terugkomen om te melden dat ze niet kunnen wisselen (en danmaakt het niet uit welk bedrag het is), en vragen je om voor het wisselgeld nog wat anders te kopen uit hij kraampje. Wij herkende dit onderhandelingsmodel nog niet (op onze reizen naar Zuid-Oost Azië kwam dit niet voor). Dus bedenk wat je voor het wisselgeld wil hebben, geef het als fooi of maak gewoon lekker op zijn Hollands ruzie om je wisselgeld te krijgen. Maar bedenk wat je wil.

title: Not What it Appears
text: Some interesting African products but tmany stalls appear to be fronted by an english speaking assistant with the stall owner in the background. Very similar products to many other local markets. Quite surprising that the stallholders were unhappy if you wouldn't enter the stall, but often thanked you for entering even if you didn't make a purchase.

title: A few tricks
text:
The trick is when dealing with the stallholders is first of all go and look at what you are wanting to buy get a feeling for the price walk away go and have a drink then take the money out of your purse or pocket and having your hand so that when you go back you tell them that this is all you have money talks louder if they can see it and you will get everything at roughly one third of the price they are wanting

Try it it works

title: Very nice arts and crafts!
text:
Very nice arts and crafts! Be adviced, take a good trusty guide for the best prices!
You can find almost everthing nice there. Best wood carvings in town. And after shopping you can drink a beer at ALEX across the street.

title: run the guantlet
text: Cheap nic naks in small stalls found at the top end of the strip. Most stalls sell similar products, tie dyes, wood carvings fridge magnets etc. Be prepared to barter and expect to get a bit mithered and hassled as you try to look round. Go early before all the stalls are set up and you will find things much cheaper than inside the hotels themselves.

title: De plek voor souvenirs in Kololi
text: Twee keer geweest. In keer eind van de middag toen erg druk en nog een keer vroeg in de morgen rond half negen om wat laatste souvenirs te kopen. Dat was ideaal. Nog niet alles was open, maar er was voldoende keuze en de verkopers waren ook nog niet 'opgestart', zodat je rustig kon kijken zonder dat ze opdringerig werden. Grote variëteit aan handgemaakte souvenirs en stoffen. Uiteraard moet je hier wel flink afdingen.

title: Super markt!
text: Een grote chaos en daardoor erg leuk! Je kunt er veel leuke stoffen kopen om een Afrikaanse jurk te laten maken.

title: Kleine toeristen markt
text: Kleine markt waar je voornamelijk houtsnijwerk en andere Afrikaanse handgemaakte souvenirs kunt kopen. Wel moet je afdingen en voor ongeveer één derde van de vraagprijs een deal sluiten.

title: What an experience
text:
Talk about busy, colourful, sights you wouldn't see in a market in the UK. Our taxi driver had his number plates removed by the police for parking in the wrong area and then had to pay a fine to get them back. 
Plenty of opportunity for a good haggle and good humoured banter. You can buy spices, chickens, fabrics, clothes, belts, shoes, pretty much anything you want.

title: All the same
text: At this market you will find the same souvenirs as on Serekunda Market or Brikama.  The only difference is that they are more expensive as this market is for tourists.

title: Very nice Market
text: A real nice market with awesome people who all want to sell u something. Best time to go is around the muslim prayer time. You will find what u will looking for here although most vendors sell the same things

title: VERY NICE CRAFT MARKET
text:
this is well stocked craft market. but if you travel to Baqau. there is a craft market there will be lot cheaper plus they sell amazing hand made wood ornaments.
senegambia as a whole is just over priced restaurants supermarkets. everything over priced for tourists. I went pharmacy for some ankle sock and creams wanted 1200 dalassi.
went to pharmacy in Baqau and kololi and was half price. same restaurants look for local restaurants. there is a kaddy kaddy gambia food jus round corner. full plate lamb and rice 50 dalassi. it's not glam though. for fruits there is stalls at traffic lights or go serekunda. everything is cheap there. there are wholesale shops for soft drinks and provisions.

title: Veel mooie handgemaakte spulletjes.
text: Hier vind je veel zaken die elders goedkoper te krijgen zijn. Zo dicht bij het Senegambia hotel liggen de vraagprijzen toch wat hoger dan bijvoorbeeld op de markt in Serekunda of Brikama. Als je echt iets wilt hebben is afdingen een must. Begin met een kwart van de vraagprijs en ga niet al te veel omhoog met de prijs die je wilt betalen.

title: Craft as Craft can
text: Very well sorted craft market - mostly statues, woodcarvings, paintings, clothes and even thimbles (I bought 2 for a collector)

title: Leuk om gezien te hebben
text: Je moet wel Goed in je schoenen staan om stevig af te dingen. PRodukten zijn ver over de prijs. Dat vond ik wel een beetje jammer.

title: Great fun
text: We had a great couple of hours haggling for a few trinkets to take home to family. I was shown how to play the local game consisting of some beans and a wood carved long dish I think she said it was called Baku Baku. Everyone was very friendly and just want you to buy from them, I laughed and explained to one lady I didn’t have enough money to spend on every stall, she laughed to so a polite no thank you and I’m all spent up was enough for them to stop, but we never really felt like it was a shark frenzy we thought everyone was very friendly, and would happily go again again for an hour or two.

title: The same old things
text:
We had a quick look around the Senegambia craft market which most of the stalls were exactly the same selling wooden carvings which were dusty as been sitting about also bracelets and a few ladies sarongs but nearly all the same items.
Nothing we wanted but they were very good prices for those interested as competitive pricing due to all the stalls having the same things.
It is nice to see all the bright colours and the people were very friendly.

title: Great for presents
text:
Nice relaxed market without much hassle. Usual bartering skills required but good fun. Wife bought usual wooden carving and stuff for presents to take home (or tat as I call it)   
Easy to find at crossroads on the strip. 
Pleasant way to spend an hour and support the local trade

title: Mercadillo tipico africano
text: He visitado el pais varias veces y me suelo alojar en esta zona y siempre me doy una vuelta por este mercado, son unos cuantos puestos en los que venden  màs o menos lo mismo, figuras, manteles, pulseras, vestidos.. y en los que puedes regatear y hacer amigos entre los vendedores, merece la pena visitarlo...

title: Leuk marktje
text: Leuk marktje, geen enorme gehassle maar ze doen wel hun best om je met een leuk verhaal iets te verkopen. Veel van hetzelfde.

title: gezellig om eens over te lopen
text: Je wordt langs alle kanten aangeklampt maar zonder dat het enerverend wordt. Deze mensen moeten immers leven van hetgeen ze hier verkopen en ze hebben veelal hetzelfde in de aanbieding. We hebben hier toch wat houtsnijwerkjes ( sleutelhangers, flessenopener, gezelschapsspel, ...) en enkele batik-doeken  gekocht. Niet vergeten om te onderhandelen over de prijs: dat hoort er bij.

title: Veel troep
text: Deze craft market is niet echt bijzonder. Er wordt voornamelijk troep verkocht. Verkopers zijn opdringerig.

title: Bra lokal marknad
text:
Stor och bra marknad för lokalbefolkningen, trånga gränder och mycket att se.
Kryddor, kläder, husgeråd, färsk fisk och levande djur. 
Gå dit på förmiddagen, då det är svalare.

title: Large and colourful, very busy
text: Lots to see, probably not much you would want to buy, great to experience local life and ways and flies!

title: Quaint
text:
Lots of little stalls selling carvings etc 
Like everywhere in The Gambia the try to get your business but just say no thank you

title: Craft Market
text: Took a walk around this market, met some great people, my wife had her hair platted with extensions by Ramada and her daughter (stall no. 48) and it looks fantastic, whilst I waited I ended up playing a game of Wawaw and drinking green tea with one of the stall holders.  I and see Jimmy (stall 55) great guy to barter with.  Will visit again.

title: Small and quaint
text: This was a lovely little market designed to sell to tourists. Slightly more expensive than going to the city market, but we enjoyed the banter.

title: Nice relaxed market for clothes and bracelets
text: Lots of the same stuff, but nice to walk around during day time, than you see the best. Of course everybody wants you to enter their shops...

title: Craftmarkets
text:
It is a craftmarket like there are a lot in the Gambia. It is just nice but small.
So just pass it by and if not; you not miss a thing

title: An experience
text:
If you can handle high pressure selling and sob stories go for it. Not much to see as all stalls very much the same. Great if you want wooden crafts, jewellery or clothing but not much else.
Worth a visit as it’s true Gambia but it’s hard work they all want your time and your money

title: marktbezoek
text:
Het is een heel grote markt.
Alles is heel laag, dus mijn man 1,98 m. moest constant gebukt lopen
Erg leuk om te zien.

title: Great stuff to buy
text: One stop shopping for your crafts and what not. Great varieties from local jewelries, masks, painting and so on.

title: Feilschen ist Pflicht
text: Kleiner Handwerkermarkt mit diversen Souveniers. Man sollte unbedingt feilschen um einen guten Preis zu erhalten. Ruhig und bestimmt, so geht es am Besten.

title: Difficult to say no
text: We found, of all places we visited in The Gambia, the salesmen and women at this market the most 'agressive'. There are some nice crafts on sale but every single person literally drags you into their shop. They put stuff in the hands of our todler to make us feel obligated to buy. Of course they want to make money, but this was to much for our taste.

title: Handy little craft market for Senegamia area browsers,,.
text: Situated at the top of The Strip service road next to Sara and opposite Alex. Africa brik-a brak  that you can barging for, some import not local at all. Useful that you can get some repairs done and if you know what you want some things made.  I found a contact at Alex bar that got be a good pair of sandles hand resoled and sown D250, throw away case in UK.  And a piece of silver work made up from a photo. Again reasonable but made off site from market so took a few days.

title: Shopping
text: We meet a guy in a bar one night who said he could make carvings of our pets, so I asked if I could see his work and it was spot on, we agreed a price I messaged a photos of the dogs and paid a deposit, he issued a receipt with phone number and all info, if you want anything like this go to unit 12, you will not be disappointed. Also the lady in 13 is quite aggressive and very pushy so I bought a Gambian shirt of a polite lady in 14 hassle free

title: Geen rustig bezoekje
text: Helaas leren ze het niet af, ze trekken je bijna overal naar binnen. Iets rustig bekijken is hier onmogelijk, zo jammer dit. Dan maar naar de serunda Market.

title: Do all your Gambian gift shopping in one place!
text:
Senagambia Craft Market is many things: busy, fascinating, unchanging and exciting. 
I first visited in the late 90s and I'm almost convinced the same stuff was still on sale. The traders are still extremely polite but can be very pushy and the craftspeople who work in the market are still making wonderful stuff at a price that is unbeatable - but you do need to haggle. 
The woodcarvers near the entrance are a lovely bunch of lads. They work so hard to produce really well made items. I commissioned a carved elephant and collected it the very next day. It might be as well to remember that there is a weight limit on planes as that almost turned into a very expensive elephant indeed. Fortunately I got away with it...
Don't be afraid to haggle and remember that the price given for the goods on sale can be reduced if you push - just, not too much eh? Its better when both parties get a good deal.
Enjoy the market and make sure you go right to the very end where there is a stall that promises no hassle. Just don't believe a word of it! lol.
The market takes about an hour or two to look around properly. I returned several times and found something new to look at on each occasion.

title: Peter crowe
text: The craft market situated at the entrance to the strip is a must place to visit  for gifts or just to look around plenty of hand made items for sale with no set prices  "haggle away  great fun

title: Holiday
text:
Love visiting  any market in the world.  This market has many stalls lots of banter,  
Lots of bracelets for sale, everyone wants you the look in their shops on their stalls.  Love chatting with the locals here people are so friendly and poilet.  Go and take in some culture.

title: Hot and traditional craft market
text: Worth a visit, but be prepared to haggle and resist the pleas to by something/ anything from every stall!

title: Too much hassling
text: Here are so many stalls selling the same thing & nearly all stall holders are part of a “ cartel”. Beware being dragged inside to negotiate a price which is always, at least double if not more the correct price. Much of the goods are substandard. Many of the carvings are of a poor quality and they are liable to split when brought home.

title: Craft Market
text: There are quite a few stalls which are packed in to a relatively small space. As always the Gambian people were very friendly and it was fun bartering with the stall holders.

title: Quelques souvenirs
text:
Endroit où trouver les souvenirs . Les gens sont pas faciles à négocier.
Mieux vaut aller à brikama, semblable mais en fait les gens de kololi achètent à brikama.
Mais ça reste un endroit agréable pour se promener.  Entrée gratuite. Ouvert de 9h à 18h.

title: Worth a nose
text: Strolled in as it was very near to our hotel, all the traders were very quick to want to pounce, this was probably as the season has just started but they were all friendly enough

title: nice little market
text: Nice little market. Well worth a visit and dont forget to barter when you get there. It is also right on the beach and next to Dominos bar

title: An experience not to be missed
text: If you like to haggle go here, there is lots of choice and you can certainly pick up an African object which has been locally made by hand

title: Not a bad option if you are not venturing.....
text: It's a good option if you are not venturing very far, don't have much time and want to get a feel of purchasing items if you are staying in that location. Bartering is the key to most transactions in Gambia.

title: Fijn bezoek
text: Leuke spullen maar erg gericht op toerisme. Weinig locals en toeristische prijzen. Wel de moeite waard om een bezoekje te brengen.

title: Heerlijke curry
text: Super lekkere curry gegeten! Het is iets duurder dan gemiddeld maar het is het wel waard! Vooraf krijg je een mandje brood. De sfeer binnen is iets minder gezellig maar het eten was heerlijk. Later kwam hier nog een zuid Afrikaanse groep optreden. Echt een aanrader als je van curry houd!

title: Nive but
text:
This craft market is located at the end of the strip on the right side near the crossing.  
yes, it is a tourist trap but on the other hand you get the opportunity to learn the game of buying souvenirs in a small market. in a bigger market like the one in banjul - albert market - is the same game only 10 times bigger .

You find literally everything there, even several times. So the best thing is to go around and see what is where available. 
Your second round you can decide what you buy where.

If you want to walk around at your pace, just tell them that you are looking around . 

when you want to buy make sure to cut the price . if it is to low, they will not sell, don't worry.

title: Hectische drukte van verkopers
text: Daar er enkel shops zijn van houtsnijwerk,textiel, soeveniers en zilver is het aanbod te kiezen zeer beperkt. Dit brengt met zich mee wanneer je eenmaal deze craftmarket hebt bezocht je geen tweede maal terug keert. Zeer beperkt aanbod, ze zouden best wat nieuwe artikelen en verschillende verkopen.

title: Even doen
text: Een overzichtelijke markt met leuke spullen.  Het werkt hier natuurlijk hetzelfde als overal, maar misschien dat je toch een leuk koopje kunt doen.

title: vol
text: De markt is vol met kraampjes en stalletjes. Overal wordt gevraagd even te kijken. Mooie spullen maar ook veel van hetzelfde

title: hout snijwerk te overvloed
text:
leuk houtsnijwerk marktje waar van alles te koop is ook diverse kleding voor leuke prijzen
aan het begin van de strip makkelijk te vinden

title: tourist attraction.
text: Whilst i was living there this market was where i had dresses made,  sandals etc. Good place to buy your presents for home. Lovely friendly people, but shop around as prices differ!

title: Veel aanbieders, weinig toeristen
text: Veel standaard aanbod maar hier zitten ook de mannen die soms prachtige producten maken. Ik heb er nu twee keer een prachtige wandelstok laten maken. Prijzen zijn hoger als in serrekunda of banjul, maar natuurlijk onderhandelbaar

title: Heel doorsnee
text:
Een afgeschermde markt met zogenaamde Afrikaanse ambachtelijke producten maar alles wat je er ziet, zie je overal. Doorsnee houten beelden, doorsnee kralen, doorsnee sandalen, kortom alles doorsnee.
Het kost gelukkig niks om naar binnen te gaan.

title: Tourist junk
text: Just the usual tourist junk in a very depressing setting. Not much pressure from the traders, but we were there in the run-up to the state of emergency, so think most traders more concerned about the future. Hope all goes well for them.

title: Good selection items, lots of haggling
text: Visited twice, 1st time didnt make it past 1 stall before we spent up. 2nd time made past 2 or 3 then we'd bought what we went for. Lots of haggling to be done.

title: Eeg leuke markt
text: Toeristische markt maar wel erg leuk en gezellig. Vreselijke aardige verkopers ook als he alleen iets vraagt of wilt kijken. Natuurlijk willen ze graag allemaal wat verkopen maar het gaat op een vriendelijke manier.

title: Far to intence
text: I don't know if it is that im a swede but i feelt very uncomfortable at this market. We took two steps in and instantly about 10 people started to grab us och talk and pull just to look at their shop, and I totally understand that.  Still it feels far to tourist like. Everyone sells the same things, wooden statues and batik fabriks and sure they are beautiful, but they was manufactured. So, nothing special but if your looking for souvenires, this is the place.

title: Gezellige markt
text:
Leuke souveniertjes op deze houtsnij markt .
Mensen zijn wat opdringerig maar wel leuk en gezellig.
En ze kunnen maken wat je wil als je een voorbeeld hebt

title: Looking for African keepsakes
text:
Visited 2 days ago
As is usual no price tags pure barter system, felt slightly pressurised to buy things we were not interested in buying. Purchased lovely peanut cookies and oranges and bananas from lady I. The photo. I am going to call her big mama but I am sure she has another name.

title: So many stalls
text:
Objectively the vast majority of the stalls had all the same stuff, but that's not a problem. Don't try to go in all the stalls! Do go with the flow and let yourself be invited in to see the wares, the stall holders try very hard. Do play a game of Gambian mankala, you do have the time, and relax about it.
Do bargain well but politely, you will get a fair price.

title: buiten kun je niet zien hoe leuk het binnen is
text:
het is wel echt voor toeristen maar er zijn een aantal bijzonder aardige ondernemers binnen, zoals de kleermaker die achter de naaimachine zit in zijn kleine shop.
En helemaal achterin op nr 46 zit Bubba, een zeer vriendelijke jongen die niet opdringerig is en je kan laten zien hoe alles wordt gemaakt, je moet dan wel met hem mee naar achter het gebouw maar daar kun je zien hoe zijn houtsnijder de figuren ter plekke maakt.

title: Interesting
text: Lots of wood hand crafted items, nice souvenirs, but you need to negotiate for a reasonable price. The vendors will ask sometime ridiculous prices but if you stay strong you can get a good bargain.

title: Overwhelming at first
text:
There are some beautiful items available in this market but the constant hassle from the stallholders can make it difficult to focus on what is available.  I found it very overwhelming at first but grew to love it. Once you realise that they are genuinely just trying to make money to feed their families it becomes more understandable.

Some of the wood carvings are works of art. Clothes are a bit hit and miss but perfect for holidays. Great for little gifts. Prices are higher than other Gambian markets as it is a tourist area. Be prepared to haggle, it is half of the fun. Keep your money close to you and enjoy the atmosphere. I've had great fun with some of the stallholders while waiting for things to be made for me.

title: Wander after lunch
text:
Had a wander after lunch. 
You can have a great time and fun with the sellers but you need two things.

Be able to drive a hard bargain.

Have good communication skills and they are good sellers but also lovely.
Enjoy

title: Interesting but not best value
text:
The Positives:
Interesting area to browse and close to all the main Kololi hotels. Good range of crafts that make good tourist souvenirs. Interesting beak from hotel/pool/beach. 

The Negatives:
The merchandise is very tourist oriented and the best prices you can get here are much higher than you can get elsewhere. Some stall holders are too pushy - once you show even the slightest interest it is hard to get away without buying something. 

Overall, it is an interesting place to visit, but if you have the time, it is much better to visit Banjul market where you will find a much wider authentic range and get lower prices.

title: Nice things, but so much hassling
text: We didn't make it past the third stall - the sellers go hard here trying to sell all of their things. However, they did have some very nice things here. Be aware that you can easily buy everything for a third of the price that they're asking if you negotiate for a bit.

title: Heel erg rustig
text: Wij waren er rond 10 uur en er waren bij elkaar maar 8 toeristen. Het was veel van hetzelfde niks verrassend gezien

title: High pressure doesn't begin to describe it
text: We stopped in the evening to view the wares and were literally dragged into some stalls. We felt like we had fallen into a shark tank during a feeding frenzy.

title: Leuk markt
text:
Neem de tijd om deze markt te bezoeken
Ga in gesprek met de verkopers 
en wees correct dan zijn zij dat ook
Wel afdingen dan kom je op een prijs uit wat voor beiden partijen
acceptabel is.

title: Good selection of crafts
text: The craft market is convenient if you are staying in the Senegambia/Kololi area.  The selection is good and the vendors willing to negotiate.  They can be aggressive, but not as pressing as other places in Gambia.

title: Leuke uitstap
text:
Leuke toeristische plek om souvenirs te kopen !!!
Mooi om de plaatselijke kunstenaars aan het werk te zien met het maken van houtsnijwerk

title: Leuke lokale markt
text: Het is echt Afrikaans, ze proberen je alles te verkopen. Gewoon duidelijk zijn en niks beloven. Dan blijft het ook leuk.

title: Shopping for souvenirs
text: If you can ignore the hassle this is a lovely place to shop. Much less hassle than at other craft markets. Most stalls will find you whatever you want if you can't see it.

title: Leuke markt voor souvenirs
text: Leuke, kleine  markt. Aardige mensen waar ik veel lol mee heb gehad. Ik heb daar heel veel houtsnijwerk gehaald en altijd netjes mijn kleingeld ontvangen. Ben je in Gambia en wil je leuke souvenirs scoren dan raad ik je aan deze markt te bezoeken. Vergeet niet af te dingen. Vinden ze leuk.

title: Onze eerste ervaring
text:
Wees op je hoede hier, je bent altijd eerste klant en wisselgeld is er niet. In plaats daarvan kan je iets anders uitzoeken en eventueel bijbetalen. 
Geen goede eerste kennismaking met Gambia

title: Een gewone lokale markt is goedkoper en afwisselender
text: Verleden jaar een lange broek daar gekocht die ik 10 minuten aangehad heb, daarna zat er een scheur in. Deze scheur laten maken, maar de broek bleek verteerd. Na 3 x uit elkaar vallen hebben we het opgegeven. Dit jaar daar 1 blouse gekocht 700 Dalassies. Op de gewone markt kochten we er 2 voor 500

title: Craft market
text: I enjoyed the hustle bustle of the market. I saw and bought many different crafts as well as getting my hair braided. The only downside is the relentless badgering of the vendors to get you to buy their wares........which is understandable but became tiresome.

title: Easy to get to but a bit over-rated...
text: Don't really buy tourist bling and do consider a lot this is actually mass produced somewhere else. Colourful and worth a few selfie photos.  A taxi ride into Serekunda will get you to a genuine Gambian trading market, realistic prices, be prepared to haggle and ask the ladies before you take photo.

title: Leuk voor wie het eerst in Afrika komt
text: Een markt  vol met Afrikaanse kleding en handwerk. Leuk voor wie een snuisterijtje wilt kopen. Helaas word je het al snel zat, omdat je geen stap meer kunt zetten tot er weer iemand in je nek springt om wat te kopen en daarover door blijft zaniken. Ikzelf vond dat vrij hinderlijk. Je moet ook goed tegen de "pingelcultuur" kunnen. Dit spel van overvragen en afdingen moet je echt liggen. Mij boeide het niet zo. Mijn vrouw was er gek op. Het is dus persoonlijk. Let er in ieder geval op geen te grote of te zware dingen te kopen zoals houtsnijwerk, want je zit met je bagagelimiet op het vliegveld. Er zit ook veel kwaliteitsverschil in de batic kleding zo hebben we gemerkt na een handwasje op de hotelkamer. Maar wat nu wel of niet goed is, daar kan ik helaas niet in adviseren.

title: Better elsewhere in Gambia
text:
The Senegambia craft market is at the left when entering the Senegambia strip, the sellers were rather pushy during this low season.
Lots of things to buy, ideal for those who don't like to leave the strip.
Prices are higher than at other places. Dark during evenings.
Try the Brikama craft market, and you will be impressed

title: Market visit.
text: Nice market with a lot of shops. They all have there own handcrafted materials. You can see nice woodwork, cloth and other things. Try the  juices at the main gate.

title: If you need anything before going back, you find it here
text: If you need anuthing to buy before going home, go there. Everything is hathered under the same roof. Remember dealing! Not the price they give to you, it's like auction

title: Laat je niet dwingen maar geniet van de African Way of shopping.
text: Superleuke Market met honderden kraampjes die natuurlijk allemaal iets aan je willen verkopen. Blijf beleefd en doe vooral je eigen ding in dit koopjesparadijs.

title: Doolhof
text: Heel groot en je zou er kunnen verdwalen. Van alles te koop. een aanrader als je de lokalen wilt zien inkopen.

title: Lots of little things to buy for familly and friends
text: Nice little market with jewary bags that kind of stuff just off the strip very busy so keep an eye on you bags nice people.

title: een echte toeristenval
text: Prijzen zijn veel duurder dan op de markt in serrekunda. De verkopers zijn ERG opdringerig. niet echt het bezoeken waard.

title: interesting caft market, nice place to visit
text: like all other gambian craft markets we can find a bit of all hand made jewellery, bags and colourfull clothes, people are very friendly and its well located at the center of Senegâmbia.

title: Very Interesting Market for Loacl Handicraft.
text:
There are many small stalls displaying hand crafted goods. Some of the carving is superb and very cheap considering the work that has gone into it.
There are of course many trinkets, drums, local clothes, carvings etc.
The people there are extremely friendly and desperate for you to buy from them, without being pushy.
A very interesting place to vist.

title: Lively market
text: Good busy and buzzy market. Very enthusiastic stall owners willing to do a deal ! Rather large too. Loads of different stalls and lovely colours abound. See the fish etc etc.

title: Nie bardzo duży market w centrum
text: Market, który da się w miare szybko przejsc i sie nie zgubić. Ludzie nagabują ale tak jest wszędzie. Pamiątki głównie materiały, koszulki, spodnie, parea, biżuteria (rózne bransoleteczki naszyjniki) i maski na ścianę. Produktów spozywczych regionalnych nie ma.

title: Matkamuistojen shoppailuun, mutta myyjät ovat hieman päällekäyviä
text:
Tämä on hyvä paikka käydä hakemassa matkamuistoja kotiin, sillä sieltä löytää niin koruja, käsintehtyjä puutuotteita kuin vaikkapa rumpuja. Muista tingata hyvin!

Myyjät ovat hieman liian innokkaita myymään ja tällaiselle suomalaiselle se tuntuu aika oudolta...

title: Manic, colourful and fun.
text: Exactly what you would expect from a West African market, busy, colourful, noisy.  Sadly couldn't find the shirt I wanted, but didn't have much time to explore.

title: handwerk op niveau
text: Heel leuk om de lokale bevolking aan het werk te zien. Vervelend is wel dat ze erg kunnen zeuren om aandacht. You are my best friend i give you best price is de meest gehoorde zin op de markt.

title: Meer van hetzelfde
text: Meer van hetzelfde. Dezelfde houten beeldjes, kettinkjes enz, Zeer drukke verkopers en uiteindelijk niet de moeite waard om te bezoeken. Spulletjes zijn gewoonweg te duur.

title: Najlepsze miejsce z pamiątkami
text: Wszystkie możliwe pamiątki kupicie właśnie tam. Szeroki wybór dzianin, wyrobów z drewna oraz magnesów na lodówkę. Te ostatnie są dość drogie w porównaniu z Europą - od 100 do 150 dalasi.

title: Drogo - w sklepach hotelowych wywoławczo połowę taniej...
text:
Ogólnie ciekawe miejsce, na którym jest mnóstwo rękodzieła oraz miejscowych ubrań - znajdziemy tam różnego rodzaju koraliki, czapki, drewniane maski i wiele wiele innych drobiazgów. Wadą miejsca jest bardzo duża "upierdliwość" sprzedających i bardzo wysokie na dzień dobry ceny... np. w sklepie hotelowym było około połowę taniej na start...
najlepszym sposobem na spokojne pooglądanie targowiska - było mówienie, iż nie zna się angielskiego...
Miejsce jest atrakcyjne dla osób chcących zobaczyć miejscowe rekodzieło.

title: Kameralnie :-)
text:
Polecam na zakup drobnych upominków .
Tylko pamiętaj o zasadzie targuj ile się da z uśmiechem na twarzy ;)

title: Craft market
text: They have a lot but they became hostile when we did not buy at there shop. It is not as nice as it use to be. Maybe better when you shop with a husband with you instead of just two women...

title: Good for gifts
text: Good for gifts, but don't buy straight away , tell them what you want to pay, walk off and they will come after you.

title: Very aggressive seller
text: Small market with lots of salesmen hunting  for the tourists. You can find the standard range of useless nick nacks. Prices are very high. The fruit seller women at the entrance are much more authentic Gambian and certainly worth a chat and spending a few dalasi for a banana or so.
My only advice is remember to haggle and don't buy first time as there are similar or same item at each stall x

title: ok for the new visitor
text: get all Gambian trinkets and stuff for presents but do haggle its a must but don't be pushed into buying what you don't want

title: leuke markt
text: aardig marktje, veelal dezelfde spullen, je kunt kleding op maat laten maken, besef dat ze teveel vragen en je moet onderhandelen

title: Better markets close by
text: I pass through this market often.  I find the people can be a bit aggressive on some visits.  I find the prices a bit higher than if I travel a bit farther to the Baku Market where I find I am not hassled as much with a larger selection of items.

title: An experience !!
text:
This  market was manic  amazing dirty unbelievable place they were selling chickens fruit Shea butter handbags clothes food aluminium cooking pots  and everything else you could think of ! People were pushing wheelbarrows full of stock in narrow walkways full of people ! The noise was incredible but all the people were smiling ! Women had babies on their backs or breastfeeding whilst selling the goods ! 
There were hundreds of stalls all the same I cannot believe they ever sold it all if anything !  But you have to go to believe it

title: Veel van hetzelfde
text: Zoals op zoveel handwerk marktje in Gambia zie ook hier veel van hetzelfde. Armbandjes, houtsnijwerk in verschillende kwaliteiten, stoffen en jurkjes. Maakt niet zoveel indruk.

title: Waste of time
text:
Can't really agree with the positive past reviews of this small overly priced market. 

Every vendor uses the same selling phrase...
"As I'm their first customer...I'll get a special price "!!!

The inflated prices are higher than hotel and other markets. 

Of course I bartered but the price still ended up higher than other places. And no...I am very good at this. I'm world travelled and yet their prices are not really negotiatable. 

Have a quick mooch but don't go past 1800. It shuts which is a shame as during the day there's no atmosphere. 

Would I go again.....?  No

Go to Serrekunda Market instead.

title: Wat een gastvrijheid
text: Leuke markt met hele aardige mensen. Veel handwerk. Willen uiteraard graag verkopen. Wie niet in Gambia. Jaw the Musickman maakt mooie spullen. Gezellig aanschuiven en praten met elkaar. Helemaal top.

title: Good experience but lots of hassel
text:
Enjoyed looking round, we did get hassled to buy everything though.  We did buy some drums which were excellent.

A nice experience just stay strong you can say no!

title: It is what it is .
text: As per tittle it is what it is ,, worth a look , you will be hassled but you will be anywhere like this in TG ,, but most of the stalls sell the same thing ,,but hey you are in Africa .

title: would sell more with less hassle
text:
love having a look around the market but tends to be a rush as you do get a lot of hassle to buy 
if store holders gave you time to look at your own pace they would sell a lot more

title: Kort bezoekje waard
text: Aardig, maar niet bijzonder. Je moet Gambia een beetje kennen om te weten hoe je met de mensen om moet gaan.

title: Cultural experience!
text: Nice little market for proper Gambian souvenirs.  All the stalls are mainly the same and sell the same things, carvings, jewellery, fabrics and bags.  The sellers will try and get you into their shop and force you to buy their goods.  If you don't want it, just a polite 'no thank you' and move on.  There is no fixed price on anything so they will ask you for your best price.  If you ask them to give you a price, barter down until you are satisfied.  I bought a nice wooden carving there where the guy told me 850 dalasis.  I ended up paying 300!

title: Good to have look at least two or three times.
text: You may find there a lot of wooden hand made masterpieces. If you like some thing but you are still not fully convinces you may ask to refresh colours before buying. The wooden masterpieces are really good but sometimes they lack of colours. Sandpaper or paint to wood would be of great use as a present. I bought on stall 77 from charming and very gifted guy huge chess (50 x 50 cm) with terrific big figures (11-17 cm).

title: More Relaxed than Serekunda
text:
A good collection of stalls selling jewellery, wood carvings, batik, accessories etc. Most of the stalls sell similar things to each other but lovely items nonetheless. The locals will hustle for business but in a milder manner than the stalls in Serekunda. It is not so hectic so you have more time to browse and consider. I wish more tourists visited the market as the locals there really need your business - many of them perhaps only selling one item a day,

My favourite stall was Roy's which is located towards the back (so make sure you don't leave him out or spend all your money too early!) He had a wonderfully carved giant crocodile that had taken him over 2 months to make. I would have loved to have purchased it but my budget would not have given him the fair price he deserved. He was also a very lovely man and advertises his stall as being 'hassle free' and that's exactly what it was.

title: A walk through the life of a Gambian Craftsman
text:
I wouldn't necessarily say that this market is any cheaper than anywhere else ,nor would I recommend it for those of you who don't like a 'hand's on approach' to business... But if you are curious, I urge you to speak to some of these traders to find out the story behind it all. 

For example, one individual, real name yusupha who calls his stall at the very back of the market 'Roye's' had carved a lifesize crocodile out of wood, it had taken him 3 months to intricately carve all the amazing detail and yet was prepared to start bartering at the equivalent of £25 for it (picture attached)

Some reviews call some of these people's products tat or knock offs from serrekunda market. Please reflect on your ignorance for one moment.

A lot of these people know anything else than the artistry of these crafts, they may be illiterate in some cases but can create amazing things. So spending an hour or so down this fascinating part of the otherwise westernised senegambia strip will truly open your eyes.

 There are some brilliant unique items to buy, which unlike the shops on the strip, go directly to the traders, who deserve it for their tireless effort. 

They will be insistent, they will beg you to buy, but they appreciate your interest in their artisan trade equally. I do warn you though, that you probably won't leave empty handed, but for a fair price for everyone.

title: looking for an experience
text: Take a leisurely walk around the craft market which has fantastic local carvings & jewellry. You can have fun haggling with the locals.Try the local street food

title: Craftmarkt links op de strip
text:
Hele kleurrijke markt veel handwerk word hier gemaakt
Mensen zijn wel ietwat opdringerig ze willen graag iets aan je verkopen, wel afdingen

title: Gaat wel
text: Veel toeristische spullen, leuker om op serekunda markt te gaan kijken. Leuk om te zien en leuk om af te dingen.

title: Lots to see
text: Lots of interesting little bits to buy, you have to barter very hard and can be a little intimidating if you don't be firm. The products are usually good with lots of carvings, art and local jewellery etc, also good for little shoe repairs if needed.

title: Mostly for tourists
text: Good assortment of tourist souvenirs.Clean, close to restaurants and charter hotels. For the real thing,go to Serekunda market for 8 Dalasi in a white minivans and be prepared for a contrast....

title: Zeker bezoeken
text: De moeite waard om door te lopen. Vele kleine winkeltjes die van alles aanbieden. Een aanrader om de plaatselijke sfeer op te snuiven.

title: Niet aan ons besteed
text:
Op deze locatie - aan de strip - kun je niet verwachten dat alles authentiek is, maar dit is wel erg gericht op toeristen. We vonden de sfeer niet echt super. Wellicht omdat we één van de weinige bezoekers waren.

Overal waar je maar even stil staat wil men je iets verkopen. Als je zegt dat je alleen maar kijkt en nog niet weet wat je wilt, zeggen ze iets in de trant van "vriendelijkheid kost niets".

Wij hebben er uiteindelijk niets gekocht. We zijn sowieso meer van de herinneringen en de foto's. Maar in dit geval vonden we de producten ook niet echt iets voor ons, al is dat natuurlijk persoonlijk.

title: Moet je eens bezoeken
text: Vele kleine winkeltjes die van alles aanbieden voor de toeristen, gemoedelijke sfeer wanneer je om kan gaan met de afrikaanse gewoonten. Zijn er koopjes te doen, hangt ervan af wat je zoekt en er wilt voor geven.

title: Not bad but not great
text: Theres a lot of hassle, but thats what you can expect from anywhere here. Most of the stalls have the exact same things but there are a couple of very nice ones selling a few nicer pieces at the far end of the market. For a more authentic experience, go to the Serrekunda craft market.

title: Zeker het bezoeken waard
text: Aan het begin van de strip ligt deze craftmarket. Niet bijzonder, want er zijn veel van dit soort marktjes in Gambia, maar vanuit ons hotel liepen we er zo heen. Het vormt een soort gemeenschap, want als je iets bij 1 stalletje niet vindt, dan haalt de verkoper het gewoon bij een ander stalletje vandaan. Het houtsnijwerk is in het algemeen niet van hoge kwaliteit qua afwerking. Er zit links achterin wel een goede houtsnijder. Op bestelling is alles te maken. Afdingen is net zoals overals in Gambia een spel dat gespeeld moet worden.

title: Hustle and bustle but mostly just hassle
text:
Overall

Lots to see, a small market and somewhere you could spend everyday browsing. The merchandise is mostly wood carvings, key rings, material bags and general touristic souvenirs. 

However it is such a shame because it's just not worthwhile rooting around given the amount of hassle you get to enter the stalls and buy something.

Vendors favourite words "come inside it does not cost anything to look and then you go" fat chance! You will be harassed to go in and harassed until you buy something!

They are very friendly people, the Gambians. However they have not realised that they are likely to sell more if they back off a little and let tourists browse.

Worth a visit to see the market but we have been here for four days and still have not mustered the courage to return.

title: Leuke kleine markt aan het begin van de strip
text: De Senegambia Craft Market is een kleine maar gezellige markt aan het begin van de strip waar ze houtsnijwerk, textiel, sieraden en heel veel souvenirs verkopen. Alleen maar kijken is haast onmogelijk, iedereen zal proberen je wat te verkopen. Vriendelijk aangeven dat je alleen maar wilt kijken, doet wonderen. Afdingen is ook op deze markt een must!

title: Geweldige ervaring
text: Erg leuk als je gewoon de tijd neemt om met de mensen te praten en even naar hun handel te kijken ze waarderen het als je de tijd voor ze neemt en zullen het je dan zeker niet kwalijk nemen als niets koopt

title: Hmm . . it all rather looked the same
text: Near the top of the strip, the craft market seems to be stocked with imported goods than locally crafted ones, and most of the stalls looked very similar.  There were some batik stalls which broke up the monopoly of the bangles, beads and baubles most of the other stalls had

title: leuk, maar commercieel
text: Het is een leuke markt, de spullen worden ook daadwerkelijk daar gemaakt, maar je wordt erg lastig gevallen om ook daadwerkelijk wat te kopen.

title: not very interesting
text: A lot of standard tourist nic nacs and every man/woman tries to get you in his job. At the entrance you've a few fruit stalls with really nice ladies working there, without the aggressive approach.

title: Leuk klein lokaal marktje
text:
De moeite waard om even over het marktje te lopen, allerlei toeristische dingen te koop, en vriendelijke verkopers.
Bij de ingang staat een klein winkeltje ( mama africa) hier zit een lief oud vrouwtje die oa sigaretten verkoop tegen normale prijzen.

title: Mooi materiaal maar zeer opdringerig
text: Je vindt er alles om met een leuk souvenir naar huis te gaan maar zeker afdingen want hun prijzen swingen de pan uit !

title: Please visit !
text: You can get all your need here ..Try  to be fair and not to beat their price down to much ! These peoples work hard all day  making there goods They need your support !

title: Типичный туристический рынок
text: Хороший рынок с большим выбором туристических сувениров. Начальные цены достаточно высокие, поэтому обязательно нужно торговаться. Можно купить неплохие поделки местных жителей.

title: Mooie spullen
text: Deze zat bij onze 2-daagse tour door de binnenlanden van Gambia. Erg opdringerig, maar gewoon aangeven dat je komt om te kijken. Als je wat wil kopen, rekenen ze Toubab prijzen, voorbeeldje. Een kom en een schaal vragen ze 1700 dal. voor, dan is het meest handige om bv 100 te bieden. Veel te laag.. uiteindelijk zal je op een paar honderd uitkomen 700. VOnd ik een prima prijs.

title: Mercado de souvenirs
text:
Es un mercado chiquitillo en el que venden en casi todos los puestos lo mismo. Figuras de madera de diferentes tamaños, timbales, collares, pulseras, etc...
Si os gusta el regateo puede ser entretenido, puedes comprar cosas a muy buen precio.
Si solo quereis daros una vuelta y no comprar nada es mejor k no os acerqueis a mirar nada porque te lo intentaran vender SI o SI.
Son bastante insistentes.

title: Running the gauntlet
text: I love this craft market but it is not for the faint-hearted.  If you love to barter, don't mind a bit of hassle as you try to find what you are looking for, then you could really enjoy yourself here. Nice little local café at the entrance where for just a little money you can sample the local food, fresh fruit and cold drinks available too at the entrance.  My advice here is to keep your sense of humour, don't get dragged inside the stalls as you WILL not get out without buying something you may not want, but enjoy the fun, the bartering and the genuine openness of the lovely Gambian people. They are trying to earn a living, if you respect them, they will respect you.  Never pay the asking price, it will usually be at least double what they expect you to pay! Fabulous clothes and jewellery and lots of wonderful wooden artefacts to take home as souvenirs. There are even tailors who will whip up an outfit for you in very little time for very fair prices.  Happy shopping and smile!

title: Great experience
text: Always worth a visit when staying in Kololi. If in doubt take an official guide with you. Excellent value. They really know their stuff and will help you with any haggling, language difficulties etc.

title: market day
text: i went to the market every time i went to gambia great experience but keep in mind you will get pulled in every stall and they think you should buy from everyone you have to be harsh and say no a lot and only pay half of what they ask or less and be willing to walk away go back the next day and you will get a good deal

title: Great for souvenirs
text: Great market for souvenirs! The stall owners can be pushy, but remember you don't have to buy everything they ask you too!

title: Great shopping
text: Barta everyone sells similar things.. Material heaven bangles jewellery and ornaments, a must visit for all

title: Souvenir heaven
text: It's a nice market if you want to buy some souvenirs for the people at home. Everybody wants to sell so don't be intimidated by them.  I had a jumpsuit made by hand and I love it!

title: nice items
text: was an experience, was quiet at this time of year, you do get hassled but think thats part of the experience.

title: Good for some souvenirs
text: This is a very small craft market in the strip, where you can buy some souvenirs and you don't have to suffer the terrible smell of bigger markets such as the one in Banjul. Ready yourself for sellers telling you to stop at their stall constantly and some haggling.  It opens around 10 am and opens around 8 pm.

title: Nothing out of the ordinary.
text: Lots of beads, clothing, beachwear, trinkets, wooden articles all rough hewn, nothing much to catch my eye and a bit too pushy stall vendors for my liking.

title: Great   shopping  a  must,
text:
A  must,  great  place  a  bit  rough  under  foot  in  places but  the  people    selling  do  bother  you  a bit
but  a  polite  no  thanks  does  the  job,  I  just  love  the  atmosphere  with  the  bartering  to  get  bargins   I  will
be  back in  November  2015   and  back  to  the  market,

title: A good place to buy pressies for friends back home
text:
However, it can be a bit too pushy for you to buy something.  I wish the traders would back off and just let you have a good browse, take it in and buy what you want.  

However, not a bad place to be.

title: Opdringerig...druk
text:
Nooit meer!!!!
Hele nare ervaring. Echter:
Het is een Gambia-ervaring en beleving vanuit mijn ervaring. Ik was hier samen met een goede vriendin. Algeheel verblijf was een drama. Nooit rust vanwege opdringerigheid.  Ik heb geleerd mezelf voortaan altijd in te lezen voordat ik een reis boek. Tip: nooit als vrouwen alleen op stap gaan naar deze markt, tenzij je er bekend bent.

title: Very nice place
text:
A very nice and friendly place. Lots of excellent crafts and good prices. 
Friendly people.
Recommended for everyone.

title: Craft Market
text: this craft market is nice and pleasant to walk round but you do get stopped a lot with the stall holders so it takes longer to get round, all the stalls seem to be selling the same stuff

title: Nice crafts but pricey
text: Its a lovely place to visit but you have to be armed with your haggling skills if you intend buying when go here as things are abit pricey and sellers alway try to out-buck you for a higher deal

title: A busy place
text:
The craft market is purely for the tourists but the skills on show are long lost in the UK.
The woodcarving, tie and die fabrics, ceramics, stuff made from rubbish and turned into art... brilliant.

title: gambia at its best.
text: people are nice,very polite,we ate a lot outside of the hotel&the senegambia strip with the locals.if u ask a local what he /she wants to eat its always chicken.

title: OK if you like wood carvings and batik
text: You need to haggle or you wil pay over the odds. Not a lot to buy unless you like wood carvings ,batik and beaded jewellery.

title: meeting locals
text: very interesting visit although the smell at certain stalls can be sickly. one thing to be wary of is some of the locals do not like you taking photos or videos of them. they can get annoyed with you. something to do with taking the spirit out of their bodies.

title: Avoid at all costs
text: The bumsters are really out in force here. Every cubicle feels like a danger zone. You get hassled non stop and I felt very threatened and could not wait to get away.

title: kleine gezellige markt
text: De Senegambia Craft Market is een kleine maar gezellige markt in de buurt van het Senegambia hotel. Er worden vooral souvenirs voor toeristen aangeboden. Vaak spullen die niet in Gambia geproduceerd zijn.

title: Overpriced
text: Expect quite a lot of hassle; much more interesting and better value at Serrekunda market (which is probably the source of many of the goods on sale here!)

title: bargain hunting
text: a lovely market brilliant for carvings and afican jewellery etc lots of fun bartering offer then about a third of the price they quote please visit Gambia no ebola there they need tourism

title: Geweldige markt
text: zeg dat je rustig wil kijken, en alles wil zien en niet van opdringerige verkoop houdt, en alles komt goed

title: leuke markt , niet al te groot
text:
leuke dingen , maar rustig kijken valt niet mee .
als je ergens kijkt moet je gelijk in de shop komen want kijken kost niets , hahahaa ja dat weten we .

title: Mobbed
text: We cannot tell you too much as we didn't stay long enough! You were mobbed from all sides as soon as you enter and it can be intimidating. What we did see was very run ofthe mill tourist tat tha t you get in all holiday resorts. There is no such thing as browsing in this market, I wouldn't recommend going although with very little else to do in the so called resort I guess they have a captive market.

title: Plenty to see and do
text: Very busy, great to experience African life.  Haggle and hunt for some bargains!  You can buy anything here from fish, meat and vegetables to cocoa butter moisturiser to clothes dye!  We bought some pencils to give out to local children in the villages.

title: Typical market
text: Good market with plenty to browse around, be ready to barter and you will have a great experience all tastes catered for!

title: good local market
text: all locals go here,great market to get the local feel of gambia,we had local guide,explained everything,not much to buy,but great experience

title: Nothing bad, just all a bit the same as any other.
text: The stalls are all very much the same as you find else where, carvings, shells, jewellery, drums, cloths etc. Store holders, not too hasslesome like some others. Didn't buy anything as nothing that took my eye. The ladies selling fruit and nuts are nice and very friendly, would go there again to get supplies. Do drive a hard bargain though.

title: worth a visit
text: was fun bartering give it a go!!  lots of tourist items to buy cheaper than the hotels, so worth a visit

title: Crowdy but interesting
text: Definitely a place to have a look at for the brave. Be aware of the hassling. Be firm but polite and there is a lot of goodies to find.

title: great
text: a great place to pick up a bargin. Do not be put off by the haggling they do expect it. A good tip is to go in the evening about 7 before they close

title: Senegambia Craft Market
text: This is Africa! expect to be hassled, expect to be cajoled, expect to bargain for items. Always be smiley and pleasant, ideally the first time you visit look only, do n't touch or even ask prices. Reflect on what you want and return another day, then look and touch ! The products are cheap anyway but always barter, excellent fabric, wood carvings and jewellery.

title: Local craftsware as usual
text: The craft market is nearby the "Strip" and you find all craft workers concentrated on one spot. So not many sellers borders you on the beach and in the streets.

title: Leuk
text: Hier maken ze allerlei handwerkjes. tafelkleden,doeken,beelden en sieraden bijvoorbeeld op de traditionele manier

title: hassled
text: would of loved to of stayed and shopped here as such beautiful things, but was hassled too much and to afraid to look. if they didn't keep pestering you ,would og bought things, as it was we just left with nothing

title: Do it and try it
text:
Try this craft market, nice people and they have it all, good prices with quality products.
Visit stand number 56 - ask for Rake - Quality products and good prices.

title: leuk!
text: erg leuke markt. Je gaat er zoals je vaker kunt lezen nooit met lege handen naar huis. En als je met meer naar huis gaat dan dat je dacht te willen kopen, dan heb je teveel betaald ;-) maar iedereen wil graag iets verkopen! het kost allemaal niets, dus al is het maar een gezellig gekeurd bamboo armbandje, neem het gezellig mee!

title: Loop je nooit zonder iets weg
text: Vriendelijk verkopers van eigen gemaakte houten dingen. Je bent altijd welkom om een hapje mee te eten tijdens de lunch, wat ik heb gedaan. Kom zeker een keertje terug voor nog meer moois.

title: not your typical market
text: A bit hectic but interesting, noisy  but friendly, some of the stall holders tried their very best but alas not all were successful

title: Good experience
text:
Very busy and bustling market, lots of stalls selling, fruit/veg products, fabrics souvenirs and local craft items.
Be prepared for the selling culture and to haggle down the prices of items.

title: What an afull place
text: Not only they pretend to make it by themselves (all is imported from abroad) they will surround you and all at the same time try to drag you to their shop (often arguing with you) that they have what you want (even though I say nothing what I am looking for). If you want a souvenir then go in there in group with something on your mind and leave quickly or you can but at shops.

title: Leuke markt met lokale handnijverheid
text: Een ruime keuze van lokaal gemaakte houtsnijwerk, sieraden en textiel. Flink onderhandelen is gebruikelijk.

title: Leuke markt
text: Leuke kleine markt om even over heen te lopen. Jammer dat je door alle verkopers aangeklampt wordt om iets te kopen. Daardoor ben je het snel beu en ben je weer snel weg.

title: Silly prices African craft market
text: A good selection of arts and crafts, some nice pieces and some not so nice.  The prices are ridiculous at the offset coupled with pushy overzealous sellers.  These things cost pittance to make in comparison to the retail.  Their is a premium to pay as a foreigner and this is exploited relentlessly by sellers trying to sell goods at far beyond their worth.  You can haggle but you will never be able to pay a fair price.  If you crave attention and have money is not a concern then you will like this place and they in turn will love you.

title: SENEGAMBIA CRAFT MARKET
text: Senegambia Craft Market is right on the beautiful tourist strip at Kololi.  To get there, head down the Bertil Harding Highway southbound until you get to the Senegambia Junction.  The Highway and Junction are bitumen roads straight from Banjul Airport, which really helps as many roads are not surfaced in Gambia.  The Craft Market is right on the crossroads and surrounded by Restaurants such as the excellent Gaya Art Café on the highway and popular African Queen Restaurant just around the corner near Totties Nightclub.  The Craft Market is in a thriving tourist area and there you will find many locally made souvenirs to buy and bring home while stopping off to have a drink or meal in the area on the way to or from Kololi Beach.  You can watch the wood carvers making traditional African masks and ornaments.  You may see sand painters at work, buy some art or hand-made jewellery, try some local food, buy fruit and juice, and see tailors sewing on treadle sewing machines making pretty sun dresses for women and children as well as traditional African clothing.  You can even have a tailor make you an outfit, and I have had a made-to-measure dress or two made there myself.  I can personally recommend Fatou Jagne who has a tailor’s business in the market as that is where I had my first traditional African outfit made-to-measure on a trip to Gambia.  Perhaps you will even catch some djembe players in action or just buy one of these beautifully made traditional drums to take home.  I’ve seen many wrapped up going through the departures queue at Banjul Yundum Airport.  The musicians are not there all the time, but the carvers who make the djembe drums might just show you how to play one if you want to try.  Prices there vary slightly and the traders can be haggled with but please do be polite and reasonable as they have overheads to pay, families to support and “hand-made” in any part of the world takes time.  Don’t forget that materials cost money too.  Their art and crafting is their job not a hobby and they are all very nice people keen to please.  One wood carver made me a wooden fish ornament for my brother while I watched, though fish were not his usual thing to carve.  The people working there are open to suggestions and keen to help.  The thing I like about it being situated right on Senegambia Junction is that at the side of the Craft Market there is a police checkpoint and the officers there will ensure that no tourist is hassled of harassed.  It’s one of my favourite spots in Gambia and I stay in the Kololi area frequently.
